questions.title: What is ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core is an open-source, cross-platform framework for building modern, cloud-based, and internet-connected applications.
A significant aspect of ASP.NET Core is its unification of the Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern and Web API functionalities into a single cohesive model.This integration provides developers with a flexible and consistent approach for building both user interfaces and backend services.
It is a redesign of ASP.NET, with architectural changes that make it more modular, lightweight, and scalable.

questions.title: Explain the difference between ASP.NET Core and ASP.NET Framework.
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core is a lightweight, fully open-source, cross-platform successor to the Windows-only ASP.NET Framework.
Built on the modular .NET Core runtime, it delivers better performance, unifies MVC and Web API, and replaces XML-heavy configuration with simple, code-based options.
In contrast, the classic ASP.NET Framework is larger, tied to Windows, and relies on the full .NET runtime.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the Program class?
questions.answer:
The Program.cs class serves as the entry point for an ASP.NET Core application.
It contains the static void Main() function, which is the first code to be executed when the application starts. This class is responsible for configuring and building the web host, which is the foundation for serving HTTP requests.

questions.title: What are the benefits of ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
Cross-platform: runs on Windows, Linux, and macOS.
High performance & lightweight: fast execution, small footprint.
Unified web stack: single model for MVC, Razor Pages, and APIs.
Modular & testable: plug-in packages, easy dependency injection.
Cloud-ready: first-class Azure integration and container support.
Open source & community-driven: rapid updates and rich ecosystem.

questions.title: Explain the concept of middleware in ASP.NET Core. Can you provide an example of how to create custom middleware?
What is Dependency Injection, and how is it implemented in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
Dependency Injection is a design pattern used to achieve loose coupling and increase testability by injecting dependencies into a class instead of creating them within the class.
In ASP.NET Core, DI is built into the framework, and you can use the built-in container or replace it with your preferred container.

questions.title: Describe the role of the Startup class in ASP.NET Core.
questions.answer:
The Startup class is a fundamental part of an ASP.NET Core application. It contains two important methods:
ConfigureServices: This method is used to configure services such as dependency injection, logging, and other application services.
Configure: This method is used to configure the HTTP request pipeline, including middleware, routing, and error handling.

questions.title: Explain the request processing pipeline in ASP.NET Core.
questions.answer:
In ASP.NET Core, every HTTP request passes through a configurable middleware pipeline, a chain of components that each perform a task (e.g., authentication, logging, routing, serving static files) and then invoke the next link.
The same chain runs in reverse for the response. Grasping this flow is key to understanding how ASP.NET Core processes and returns web requests.

questions.title: What is routing in ASP.NET Core? How can you define routes?
What is Razor Pages in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
Razor Pages is a page-based programming model in ASP.NET Core for building web UI.
It combines the benefits of MVC and Web Forms, providing a simpler syntax for building pages with code-behind files.
It's particularly useful for building small to medium-sized web applications.

questions.title: What is Entity Framework Core, and how is it different from Entity Framework?
questions.answer:
Entity Framework Core is a lightweight, cross-platform Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) framework for .NET. It is a modern, extensible, and open-source version of Entity Framework.
While Entity Framework supports only Windows, Entity Framework Core is cross-platform and can be used in a wider range of scenarios.

questions.title: How do you handle configuration in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
Configuration in ASP.NET Core is typically handled through the appsettings.json file, environment variables, command-line arguments, and other configuration providers.
The IConfiguration interface provides access to these configuration sources, and settings can be injected into services using dependency injection.

questions.title: Explain the concept of Tag Helpers in ASP.NET Core.
questions.answer:
Tag Helpers in ASP.NET Core are a way to create reusable HTML components with server-side logic.
They enable developers to write server-side code directly in the HTML markup, making the code more readable and maintainable.
Tag Helpers are similar to HTML helpers but provide a more natural and HTML-centric syntax.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the wwwroot folder?
questions.answer:
The appsettings.json file serves as a central location for storing configuration settings for an ASP.NET Core application.
This includes various settings that govern the application's behavior, such as database connection strings, logging levels, and custom application-specific configurations.
Understanding configuration is important for managing application behavior across different environments.

questions.title: What is NuGet package manager?
questions.answer:
NuGet is a package manager specifically designed for the .NET ecosystem. It allows developers to easily discover, download, and integrate existing libraries (referred to as packages) that have been created and shared by other .NET developers into their own projects.
The project's dependencies on these packages are typically listed in the .csproj file, and the dotnet restore command is used to download the necessary NuGet packages.

questions.title: Explain the MVC (Model-View-Controller) pattern.
questions.answer:
An MVC app is split into:

Model: Data + business logic
View: UI that renders model data
Controller: Handles user input, updates the model, and chooses the view

This separation keeps concerns distinct, aiding testability and maintainability.

questions.title: What are the roles of Model, View, and Controller in ASP.NET Core MVC?
questions.answer:
Model: C# classes that store data and encapsulate business logic.
View: .cshtml files that turn model data into HTML for the browser.
Controller: Handles HTTP requests, uses the model to process or update data, then chooses a view to render.

questions.title: What is Model Binding in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer: Model binding automatically maps HTTP request data, route values, query strings, form fields, or body content, to the parameters of an action method, converting raw strings into the appropriate .NET types so the action can work with them directly.

questions.title: What is an Action Method in ASP.NET Core MVC?
questions.answer:
An action method is a public instance method on a controller that executes when a matching HTTP request arrives. It must be:

Public (non-static)
Uniquely named: overloads are not allowed

The method normally returns IActionResult (or something implicitly convertible to it), describing the HTTP response sent back to the client.

questions.title: What are the benefits of using ASP.NET Core for microservices architecture?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core is well-suited for microservices due to its lightweight nature, cross-platform support, and modular architecture.
It allows for containerization using Docker, supports multiple deployment targets, and provides built-in support for dependency injection and configuration.
Additionally, it can be easily integrated with popular microservices-oriented tools and frameworks.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the appsettings.json file in an ASP.NET Core application?
questions.answer:
The appsettings.json file is used for configuration in ASP.NET Core. It allows developers to store application settings in a structured format, including key-value pairs.
The settings can be accessed using the IConfiguration interface, and the values can be overridden based on the environment (development, staging, production) or through other configuration providers.

questions.title: Differentiate between app.Run and app.Use in middleware configuration.
What is a Request delegate in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
A request delegate is the core unit of ASP.NET Core’s middleware pipeline, a function that takes an HttpContext, processes it, and (optionally) calls the next delegate.
Middleware stacks these delegates, so each one can run logic before/after invoking the next, together completing the request-response cycle.

questions.title: How does ASP.NET Core support cross-site request forgery (CSRF) protection, and what mechanisms can be used to prevent CSRF attacks?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core provides built-in CSRF protection through anti-forgery tokens. The ValidateAntiForgeryToken attribute can be applied to controllers or actions to validate tokens.
Additionally, the @Html.AntiForgeryToken() helper can be used in Razor views to include anti-forgery tokens in forms. Other preventive measures include using the SameSite attribute for cookies and implementing secure coding practices.

questions.title: Explain the role of the IActionResult interface in ASP.NET Core. Provide examples of different types of action results.
questions.answer:
IActionResult is an interface representing the result of an action method in ASP.NET Core. It allows flexibility in returning various types of results. Examples include:
ViewResult: Renders a view.
JsonResult: Returns JSON-formatted data.
RedirectResult: Redirects to a specified URL.
ContentResult: Returns a user-defined content (string, JSON, XML, etc.).
FileResult: Returns a file.

questions.title: How does ASP.NET Core handle authentication and authorization?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core provides a flexible and extensible authentication and authorization system.
Authentication is the process of validating the identity of a user, while authorization is the process of determining what actions a user is allowed to perform.
ASP.NET Core supports various authentication providers, such as cookies, JWT, and external providers (Google, Facebook). Authorization is achieved using attributes like Authorize on controllers or action methods.

questions.title: Explain Session and State Management options in ASP.NET Core.
questions.answer:
In ASP.NET Core, a session cookie holds a unique ID per user while the session data itself stays server-side, in memory, a distributed cache (Redis, SQL Server), or a custom store.
For broader or longer-lived state, use the same caching APIs (in-memory or distributed) or persist data in a database.

questions.title: Explain the concept of model binding in ASP.NET Core. How does it work, and how can you customize it?
questions.answer:
Model binding is the process of mapping data from an HTTP request to the parameters of a controller action method.
ASP.NET Core performs automatic model binding based on naming conventions and data types.
Developers can customize model binding using attributes, custom model binders, or the FromQuery, FromRoute, and FromBody attributes to specify the source of data for binding.

questions.title: What is the role of the app.UseEndpoints method in the Startup class?
Explain the concept of View Components in ASP.NET Core. How are they different from partial views?
questions.answer:
View Components are a reusable, encapsulated unit of UI logic in ASP.NET Core, designed to be more flexible and powerful than partial views.
They consist of both a class file and a corresponding view file. Unlike partial views, View Components can have their own logic and can be invoked with parameters, making them more suitable for scenarios where a component needs to encapsulate both data and behavior.

questions.title: How does ASP.NET Core handle state management? Explain the differences between TempData, ViewData, and ViewBag.
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core supports various mechanisms for state management.
TempData is used to pass data between requests, and it is stored for a short duration (usually until the next request).
ViewData and ViewBag are used to pass data from controllers to views. The key difference is that ViewData is a dictionary, and ViewBag is a dynamic property bag. However, both are used for similar purposes.

questions.title: What are the different service lifetimes in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
In ASP.NET Core, when registering services with the dependency injection container, you can specify their lifetime. The three primary lifetimes are Transient, Scoped, and Singleton.
A Transient service is created every time it's requested.
A Scoped service is created once per request (e.g., per HTTP request in a web application).
A Singleton service is created only once during the entire application lifetime.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the IHostedService interface in ASP.NET Core, and how can it be used?
questions.answer:
The IHostedService interface in ASP.NET Core represents a background task that runs for the lifetime of the application.
Classes implementing this interface can be registered as hosted services to perform background tasks, such as scheduled jobs, periodic data updates, or other long-running processes.
This interface is commonly used with dependency injection to manage and execute background tasks.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the app.Map and app.MapWhen methods in ASP.NET Core, and how are they used?
questions.answer:
app.Map is used to branch the request pipeline based on a specified path. It allows you to configure middleware to handle requests that match a particular path or segment.
app.MapWhen is similar but allows for more dynamic conditions based on the request. These methods are useful for applying middleware selectively based on specific criteria, such as routing requests to different middleware based on the URL.

questions.title: Explain the concept of Health Checks in ASP.NET Core. How are they implemented, and why are they important?
questions.answer:
Health Checks are a way to monitor the health of an application by periodically checking its components (e.g., databases, services).
In ASP.NET Core, health checks are implemented using the Microsoft.AspNetCore.Diagnostics.HealthChecks package. They provide a standardized way to expose the health status of different parts of the application. Health checks are crucial for proactively identifying and addressing potential issues before they affect users.

questions.title: How can you handle cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) in an ASP.NET Core application?
questions.answer: CORS can be configured in an ASP.NET Core application using the Microsoft.AspNetCore.Cors package. In the Startup class, the ConfigureServices method can be used to add CORS services, and the Configure method can be used to configure CORS policies. This allows you to specify which origins, methods, and headers are allowed for cross-origin requests.

questions.title: Explain the differences between Inversion of Control (IoC) and Dependency Injection (DI).
questions.answer:
Inversion of Control (IoC) is a broader design principle where the control flow of a program is inverted – instead of a component controlling the flow, it delegates control to a framework or container.
Dependency Injection (DI) is a specific implementation of IoC, focusing on providing a way to inject dependencies into a class from an external source. In other words, DI is a way to achieve IoC.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the appsettings.Development.json and appsettings.Production.json files in an ASP.NET Core application?
questions.answer:
These files are used for environment-specific configuration settings. appsettings.Development.json contains configuration settings specific to the development environment, while appsettings.Production.json contains settings for the production environment.
ASP.NET Core automatically selects the appropriate environment-specific settings based on the runtime environment.

questions.title: How does ASP.NET Core support logging, and what are the different log levels available?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core has a built-in logging framework that supports various log providers (Console, Debug, EventSource, etc.). The available log levels are:
Trace
Debug
Information
Warning
Error
Critical
Developers can use the ILogger interface to log messages at different levels throughout the application.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the async and await keywords in C#? How are they used in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
async and await are used to write asynchronous code in C#. The async keyword is used to define a method as asynchronous, and await is used to asynchronously wait for a task to complete without blocking the thread.
In ASP.NET Core, asynchronous programming is commonly used to improve the scalability of web applications by allowing the server to handle more requests concurrently without blocking threads.

questions.title: Explain the concept of middleware pipeline termination in ASP.NET Core. How can you terminate the pipeline and short-circuit further processing?
questions.answer:
Middleware pipeline termination occurs when a middleware component produces a response without invoking the next middleware in the pipeline. This is often done using the HttpResponse object.
For example, calling context.Response.StatusCode = 404 followed by return will terminate the pipeline and send a 404 response without invoking subsequent middleware.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the app.UseExceptionHandler method in ASP.NET Core, and how can it be used to handle errors in the application?
questions.answer:
app.UseExceptionHandler configures middleware to catch unhandled exceptions in the application and generate an error response.
This is useful for providing a consistent way to handle errors and present user-friendly error pages. Typically, you would use this middleware to log errors and display an appropriate error page to users.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the AllowAnonymous attribute in ASP.NET Core, and when would you use it in your controllers or action methods?
questions.answer:
The AllowAnonymous attribute is used to specify that an action or controller should be accessible to unauthenticated users. By default, ASP.NET Core requires authentication for all requests.
Using AllowAnonymous on specific actions allows public access, even when authentication is required globally.

questions.title: How does ASP.NET Core support data validation, and what are the validation attributes available in the framework?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core supports data validation through model validation. Model validation is performed automatically during model binding.
Validation attributes, such as Required, StringLength, and RegularExpression, can be applied to model properties to define validation rules. Additionally, developers can create custom validation attributes to enforce specific validation logic.

questions.title: Explain the purpose of the ConfigureServices method in the Startup class. How is it used to configure services in an ASP.NET Core application?
questions.answer:
The ConfigureServices method in the Startup class is used to configure services for dependency injection in an ASP.NET Core application. It is where you register application services, configure options, and set up the dependency injection container.
Services registered here are available throughout the application, and it's a crucial step in the application's initialization.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the app.UseHttpsRedirection middleware, and how can it be configured to enforce HTTPS in an ASP.NET Core application?
What is the purpose of the ModelState object in ASP.NET Core, and how is it used for validation?
questions.answer:
The ModelState object in ASP.NET Core is used to store validation errors and values for model binding. It represents the state of model binding and validation for a specific request.
When validation fails, errors are added to the ModelState, and these errors can be checked in controllers to conditionally handle invalid input and return appropriate responses to the user.

questions.title: Explain the role of the IActionFilter and IAuthorizationFilter interfaces in ASP.NET Core.
questions.answer:
IActionFilter and IAuthorizationFilter are filter interfaces that allow developers to customize the behavior of controllers. IActionFilter provides hooks before and after action execution, enabling tasks such as logging or modifying the response.
IAuthorizationFilter is used for custom authorization logic. Filters implementing these interfaces can be applied globally, at the controller level, or on specific actions to modify the request or response.

questions.title: Explain the role of the DbContext in Entity Framework Core. How does it relate to database interactions in an ASP.NET Core application?
questions.answer:
The DbContext in Entity Framework Core is a crucial component that represents the session with the database.
It is responsible for tracking changes to entities, managing database connections, and facilitating the interaction between the application and the underlying database.
Developers use the DbContext to perform CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on the database through LINQ queries.

questions.title: How can you handle exceptions globally in an ASP.NET Core application?
Explain the role of the UseStaticFiles middleware in ASP.NET Core.
What is the purpose of the ModelState.AddModelError method in ASP.NET Core?
Explain the purpose of the app.UseDeveloperExceptionPage middleware in ASP.NET Core.
Explain the purpose of the FromServices attribute in ASP.NET Core.
What is the purpose of the app.UseCors middleware in ASP.NET Core?
Explain the purpose of the ITempDataDictionary in ASP.NET Core.
Explain the purpose of the app.UseMvc method in ASP.NET Core, and how is it used to configure the MVC framework in the middleware pipeline?
Explain the purpose of the [ApiController] attribute in ASP.NET Core controllers. How does it affect the behavior of a controller and its actions?
questions.answer:
The [ApiController] attribute in ASP.NET Core is used to indicate that a controller is an API controller.
It affects the behavior of the controller and its actions in several ways, including automatic model validation, binding of complex types from the request body, and automatic HTTP 400 responses for invalid requests.
It is commonly used in RESTful API controllers to simplify development and adhere to API conventions.

csharp

Copy code

[ApiController]
[Route("api/[controller]")]
public class MyApiController : ControllerBase
{
    // Actions...
}

questions.title: What is the purpose of the [Produces] attribute in ASP.NET Core controllers? How can it be used to specify the content types a controller action can produce?
Explain the differences between services.AddSingleton, services.AddScoped, and services.AddTransient in ASP.NET Core dependency injection. When would you use each?
How does ASP.NET Core support versioning for APIs?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core supports API versioning through various approaches, including query string versioning, URL segment versioning, and header versioning.
Developers can choose the approach that best fits their application's requirements. Versioning can be configured using the AddApiVersioning method in the ConfigureServices method of the Startup class.

questions.title: What is the role of the UseSwagger and UseSwaggerUI methods in ASP.NET Core, and how can they be used to document and test APIs?
questions.answer:
The UseSwagger middleware generates a JSON file containing the API documentation in Swagger format. UseSwaggerUI provides a user interface to explore and test the API using Swagger.
These middleware components are commonly used in conjunction with the Swashbuckle.AspNetCore NuGet package to automate the generation of API documentation based on the code.

questions.title: Explain the purpose of the IWebHostEnvironment interface in ASP.NET Core?
questions.answer:
IWebHostEnvironment provides information about the hosting environment (e.g., Development, Staging, Production). It can be used to conditionally configure services or settings based on the current environment.
For example, different database connection strings or logging configurations can be specified for different environments in the ConfigureServices method of the Startup class.

questions.title: Explain the purpose of the ModelState.IsValid property in ASP.NET Core. How is it used in form validation?
questions.answer:
ModelState.IsValid is a property that indicates whether the model state is valid based on applied validation rules. In form validation, this property is often checked in a controller action to determine if the submitted form data is valid.
If ModelState.IsValid is false, it means there are validation errors, and the controller can handle them accordingly, such as redisplaying the form with error messages.

questions.title: What is the purpose of the ITagHelper interface in ASP.NET Core, and how can it be used to extend HTML functionality in Razor views?
questions.answer:
ITagHelper is an interface in ASP.NET Core used to extend HTML functionality in Razor views. Tag helpers are designed to simplify working with HTML elements by enabling server-side code within the HTML markup.
Custom tag helpers can be created by implementing the ITagHelper interface, providing a way to encapsulate reusable HTML-generating logic.

questions.title: Explain the role of the app.UseHsts middleware in ASP.NET Core, and how can it enhance the security of a web application?
Explain the role of the app.UseForwardedHeaders middleware in ASP.NET Core.
How does ASP.NET Core support cross-site scripting (XSS) protection, and what measures can be taken to prevent XSS attacks in an application?
questions.answer:
ASP.NET Core provides built-in protection against cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks through automatic HTML encoding of output.
Developers can further prevent XSS attacks by validating and sanitizing user inputs, using content security policies (CSP), and applying anti-forgery tokens.
Additionally, the @Html.AntiForgeryToken helper can be used to generate tokens in forms, helping prevent CSRF attacks.
